Problem 1

Let XXX represent the tire pressure of a Formula 1 car at its peak temperature, measured in PSI. With the current tires, it is known that X∼N(32,4)X \sim \mathcal{N}\p{32, 4}X∼N(32,4). A new brand of tire is being considered, hoping that the PSI at peak temperature will be higher than 323232, such that X∼N(μ>32,4)X \sim \mathcal{N}\p{\mu > 32, 4}X∼N(μ>32,4). Suppose we collect a sample of size n=36n = 36n=36 about the peak temperature PSI of the second brand of tires, and we observe x‾=35\mean{x} = 35x=35. We are interested in testing the following hypotheses:

H0 ⁣:μ=32H1 ⁣:μ>32.\begin{aligned} H_0 &\colon \mu = 32 \\ H_1 &\colon \mu > 32. \end{aligned}H0​H1​​:μ=32:μ>32.​
  1. Derive the ppp-value for this test.
  2. Given α=0.05\alpha = 0.05α=0.05, should we reject or not reject H0H_0H0​?
Solution.

The test statistic for the scenario is

Z=X‾−μσ/n∼N(0,1),Z = \frac{\mean{X} - \mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} \sim \mathcal{N}\p{0, 1},Z=σ/n​X−μ​∼N(0,1),

since XXX is normal and the variance is known. The sample test statistic (under H0H_0H0​) is then

z=35−322/36=9.z = \frac{35 - 32}{2/\sqrt{36}} = 9.z=2/36​35−32​=9.

  1. The ppp-value is the probability of observing x‾=35\mean{x} = 35x=35 or something more extreme (i.e., numbers that give more evidence that μ>32\mu > 32μ>32). In this problem, this is

    P(Z≥9)≈0.\boxed{\P\p{Z \geq 9} \approx 0}.P(Z≥9)≈0​.

  2. We reject H0H_0H0​ at α=0.05\alpha = 0.05α=0.05.

Problem 2

Among the data collected for the WHO air quality monitoring project is a measure of suspended particles, in μg/m3\mu g/m^3μg/m3. Let XXX and YYY equal the concentration of suspended particles in μg/m3\mu g/m^3μg/m3 in the city centers of Melbourne and Huston, respectively. Using nX=13n_X = 13nX​=13 observations of XXX and nY=16n_Y = 16nY​=16 observations of YYY, we shall test H0 ⁣:μX=μYH_0 \colon \mu_X = \mu_YH0​:μX​=μY​ against H1 ⁣:μX<μYH_1 \colon \mu_X < \mu_YH1​:μX​<μY​.

  1. Define the test statistic and critical region, assuming that the variances are equal. Let α=0.05\alpha = 0.05α=0.05.
  2. If x‾=72.9\mean{x} = 72.9x=72.9, sX=25.6s_X = 25.6sX​=25.6, y‾=81.7\mean{y} = 81.7y​=81.7, and sY=28.3s_Y = 28.3sY​=28.3, calculate the value of the test statistic and state your conclusion.
Solution.

  1. Since the sample size is small and the variances are unknown but equal, the test statistic is

    T=X‾−Y‾−(μX−μY)Sp1nX+1nY∼t(nX+nY−2),T = \frac{\mean{X} - \mean{Y} - \p{\mu_X - \mu_Y}}{S_p\sqrt{\frac{1}{n_X} + \frac{1}{n_Y}}} \sim t\p{n_X + n_Y - 2},T=Sp​nX​1​+nY​1​​X−Y−(μX​−μY​)​∼t(nX​+nY​−2),

    where SpS_pSp​ is the pooled sample standard deviation. We have a one-sided test, so we reject if

    t<−tα(27)=−1.703.\boxed{t < -t_\alpha\p{27} = -1.703}.t<−tα​(27)=−1.703​.

  2. Under H0H_0H0​, μX−μY=0\mu_X - \mu_Y = 0μX​−μY​=0, so the sample test statistic is

    t=72.9−81.7sp113+116=−0.8686.t = \frac{72.9 - 81.7}{s_p\sqrt{\frac{1}{13} + \frac{1}{16}}} = -0.8686.t=sp​131​+161​​72.9−81.7​=−0.8686.

    This is not in the critical region, so we do not reject H0H_0H0​ at α=0.05\alpha = 0.05α=0.05.

Problem 3

Some nurses in county public health conducted a survey of women who had received inadequate prenatal care. They used information from birth certificates to select mothers for the survey. The mothers selected were divided into two groups:

  • Group AAA: mothers who said they had ≤5\leq 5≤5 prenatal visit.
  • Group BBB: mothers who said they had ≥6\geq 6≥6 prenatal visits.

Let XXX be the birth weight of babies from mothers in Group AAA and YYY the birth weight of babies from mothers in Group BBB. Assume that X∼N(μX,σX2)X \sim \mathcal{N}\p{\mu_X, \sigma_X^2}X∼N(μX​,σX2​) and Y∼N(μY,σY2)Y \sim \mathcal{N}\p{\mu_Y, \sigma_Y^2}Y∼N(μY​,σY2​), where σX\sigma_XσX​ and σY\sigma_YσY​ are unknown but equal. Suppose that the result of the survey is that

  • Birth weight of babies from mothers in Group AAA: 494949, 108108108, 110110110, 828282, 939393, 114114114, 134134134, 114114114, 969696, 525252, 101101101, 114114114, 120120120, 116116116
  • Birth weight of babies from mothers in Group BBB: 133133133, 108108108, 939393, 119119119, 119119119, 989898, 106106106, 131131131, 878787, 153153153, 116116116, 129129129, 979797, 110110110
  1. Give a 95%95\%95% confidence interval for μX−μY\mu_X − \mu_YμX​−μY​.
  2. Test H0 ⁣:μX=μYH_0 \colon \mu_X = \mu_YH0​:μX​=μY​ against H1 ⁣:μX≠μYH_1 \colon \mu_X \neq \mu_YH1​:μX​=μY​ at significance level 0.050.050.05.
  3. Compute the associated ppp-value.
  4. Redo part (1)-(3), but do not assume σX=σY\sigma_X = \sigma_YσX​=σY​, by pairing up the mothers of the two groups in the order they appear.
Solution.

For parts (1)-(3), since the variances are assumed to be equal, the test statistic is

T=X‾−Y‾−(μX−μY)Sp1nX+1nY∼t(nX+nY−2).T = \frac{\mean{X} - \mean{Y} - \p{\mu_X - \mu_Y}}{S_p\sqrt{\frac{1}{n_X} + \frac{1}{n_Y}}} \sim t\p{n_X + n_Y - 2}.T=Sp​nX​1​+nY​1​​X−Y−(μX​−μY​)​∼t(nX​+nY​−2).

  1. A 95%95\%95% confidence interval is

    x‾−y‾±tα2(26)sp1nX+1nY=[−30.7909,2.7909]\mean{x} - \mean{y} \pm t_{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\p{26} s_p\sqrt{\frac{1}{n_X} + \frac{1}{n_Y}} = \boxed{\br{-30.7909, 2.7909}}x−y​±t2α​​(26)sp​nX​1​+nY​1​​=[−30.7909,2.7909]​

  2. Since this is a two-sided test, the critical region is

    t<−tα2(26)=−2.056ort>tα2(26)=2.056.t < -t_{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\p{26} = -2.056 \quad\text{or}\quad t > t_{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\p{26} = 2.056.t<−t2α​​(26)=−2.056ort>t2α​​(26)=2.056.

    In our case, the sample test statistic is

    t=−1.7143,t = -1.7143,t=−1.7143,

    which is not in the critical region. Thus, we do not reject H0H_0H0​ at α=0.05\alpha = 0.05α=0.05.

  3. Since this is a two-sided test, the ppp-value is

    P(T≤−∣t∣ or T≥∣t∣)=2P(T≥∣t∣)=2(1−P(T≤∣t∣))=2(1−P(T≤1.7143)).\begin{aligned} \P\p{T \leq -\abs{t} \text{ or } T \geq \abs{t}} &= 2\P\p{T \geq \abs{t}} \\ &= 2\p{1 - \P\p{T \leq \abs{t}}} \\ &= 2\p{1 - \P\p{T \leq 1.7143}}. \end{aligned}P(T≤−∣t∣ or T≥∣t∣)​=2P(T≥∣t∣)=2(1−P(T≤∣t∣))=2(1−P(T≤1.7143)).​

    From the ttt-table in the book,

    0.95<P(T≤1.7143)<0.975,0.95 < \P\p{T \leq 1.7143} < 0.975,0.95<P(T≤1.7143)<0.975,

    so the ppp-value satisfies

    0.05<p-value<0.10.\boxed{0.05 < p\text{-value} < 0.10}.0.05<p-value<0.10​.

  4. What the problem asks you to do is to treat the samples as differences, e.g., d1=x1−y1=49−133d_1 = x_1 - y_1 = 49 - 133d1​=x1​−y1​=49−133, etc. This gives us the following sample:

    d−84017−37−261628−179−101−15−15236\begin{array}{r|rrrrrrrrrrrrrr} d & -84 & 0 & 17 & -37 & -26 & 16 & 28 & -17 & 9 -101 & -15 & -15 & 23 & 6 \end{array}d​−84​0​17​−37​−26​16​28​−17​9−101​−15​−15​23​6​

    We need to test the hypotheses

    H0 ⁣:μD=0H1 ⁣:μD≠0.\begin{aligned} H_0 &\colon \mu_D = 0 \\ H_1 &\colon \mu_D \neq 0. \end{aligned}H0​H1​​:μD​=0:μD​=0.​

    In this case, we have n=14n = 14n=14 differences and the test statistic is now

    T=D‾−(μX−μY)SD/n∼t(13).T = \frac{\mean{D} - \p{\mu_X - \mu_Y}}{S_D/\sqrt{n}} \sim t\p{13}.T=SD​/n​D−(μX​−μY​)​∼t(13).

    A 95%95\%95% confidence interval is

    d‾±tα2(13)sDn=[−36.2270,8.2270].\mean{d} \pm t_{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\p{13} \frac{s_D}{\sqrt{n}} = \boxed{\br{-36.2270, 8.2270}}.d±t2α​​(13)n​sD​​=[−36.2270,8.2270]​.

    The critical region is

    t<−tα2(13)=−2.160ort>tα2(13)=2.160.t < -t_{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\p{13} = -2.160 \quad\text{or}\quad t > t_{\frac{\alpha}{2}}\p{13} = 2.160.t<−t2α​​(13)=−2.160ort>t2α​​(13)=2.160.

    The test statistic is

    t=−1.3605,t = -1.3605,t=−1.3605,

    which does not fall into the critical region, so we do not reject H0H_0H0​ at α=0.05\alpha = 0.05α=0.05. Lastly, the ppp-value is computed like before:

    p-value=2(1−P(T≤1.3605)).p\text{-value} = 2\p{1 - \P\p{T \leq 1.3605}}.p-value=2(1−P(T≤1.3605)).

    From the textbook's ttt-table, 0.90<P(T≤1.3605)<0.950.90 < \P\p{T \leq 1.3605} < 0.950.90<P(T≤1.3605)<0.95, so the ppp-value satisfies

    0.10<p-value<0.20.\boxed{0.10 < p\text{-value} < 0.20}.0.10<p-value<0.20​.

Problem 4

A stream was studied on 262626 days, half during dry weather (XXX), and the other half immediately after a significant rainfall (YYY). Assume that the distributions of XXX and YYY are N(μX,σ2)\mathcal{N}\p{\mu_X, \sigma^2}N(μX​,σ2) and N(μY,σ2)\mathcal{N}\p{\mu_Y, \sigma^2}N(μY​,σ2), respectively. The following turbidities were recorded in units of NTUs (nephelometric turbidity units):

x2.914.91.012.69.4y7.84.22.412.917.3\begin{array}{r|rrrrr} x & 2.9 & 14.9 & 1.0 & 12.6 & 9.4 \\ y & 7.8 & 4.2 & 2.4 & 12.9 & 17.3 \end{array}xy​2.97.8​14.94.2​1.02.4​12.612.9​9.417.3​

Test the null hypothesis H0 ⁣:μX=μYH_0 \colon \mu_X = \mu_YH0​:μX​=μY​ against H1 ⁣:μX>μYH_1 \colon \mu_X > \mu_YH1​:μX​>μY​ at α=0.01\alpha = 0.01α=0.01. Give bounds for the ppp-value and state your conclusion.

Solution.

Since the sample size is small and the variances are assumed to be equal, our test statistic is

T=X‾−Y‾−(μX−μY)Sp1nX+1nY∼t(8).T = \frac{\mean{X} - \mean{Y} - \p{\mu_X - \mu_Y}}{S_p\sqrt{\frac{1}{n_X} + \frac{1}{n_Y}}} \sim t\p{8}.T=Sp​nX​1​+nY​1​​X−Y−(μX​−μY​)​∼t(8).

Our observed test statistic is

t=−0.1970,t = -0.1970,t=−0.1970,

so the ppp-value is

P(T≥−0.1970)=1−P(T≤0.1970).\P\p{T \geq -0.1970} = 1 - \P\p{T \leq 0.1970}.P(T≥−0.1970)=1−P(T≤0.1970).

From the ttt-table, P(T≤0.1970)<0.60\P\p{T \leq 0.1970} < 0.60P(T≤0.1970)<0.60, so

p-value>0.40.\boxed{p\text{-value} > 0.40}.p-value>0.40​.

Thus, we do not reject H0H_0H0​ at α=0.01\alpha = 0.01α=0.01.

Problem 5

Let Y∼Bin⁡(100,p)Y \sim \operatorname{Bin}\p{100, p}Y∼Bin(100,p). To test H0 ⁣:p=0.08H_0 \colon p = 0.08H0​:p=0.08 against H1 ⁣:p<0.08H_1 \colon p < 0.08H1​:p<0.08, we reject H0H_0H0​ and accept H1H_1H1​ if and only if Y≤6Y \leq 6Y≤6. Determine the significance level α\alphaα of the test.

Solution.

The significance level α\alphaα is the probability that we reject H0H_0H0​ given that H0H_0H0​ is true. In other words,

α=P(Y≤6).\alpha = \P\p{Y \leq 6}.α=P(Y≤6).

We can use the normal approximation to a binomial distribution since n=100n = 100n=100 is large:

Z=Y100−pp(1−p)/100≈N(0,1).Z = \frac{\frac{Y}{100} - p}{\sqrt{p\p{1 - p}/100}} \approx \mathcal{N}\p{0, 1}.Z=p(1−p)/100​100Y​−p​≈N(0,1).

Then (with a continuity correction) we get

P(Y≤6)=P(Y≤6.5)≈P(Z≤6.5100−0.080.08(1−0.08)/100)≈P(Z≤−0.5529)=1−P(Z≤0.5529)≈1−0.7088=0.2912.\begin{aligned} \P\p{Y \leq 6} &= \P\p{Y \leq 6.5} \\ &\approx \P\p{Z \leq \frac{\frac{6.5}{100} - 0.08}{\sqrt{0.08\p{1 - 0.08}/100}}} \\ &\approx \P\p{Z \leq −0.5529} \\ &= 1 - \P\p{Z \leq 0.5529} \\ &\approx 1 - 0.7088 \\ &= \boxed{0.2912}. \end{aligned}P(Y≤6)​=P(Y≤6.5)≈P(Z≤0.08(1−0.08)/100​1006.5​−0.08​)≈P(Z≤−0.5529)=1−P(Z≤0.5529)≈1−0.7088=0.2912​.​

Alternatively, you can just calculate the binomial sum directly if your calculator is able to compute the binomial coefficients:

P(Y≤6)=∑k=06(100k)(0.08)k(0.92)100−k=0.3032\P\p{Y \leq 6} = \sum_{k=0}^6 \binom{100}{k} \p{0.08}^k \p{0.92}^{100-k} = \boxed{0.3032}P(Y≤6)=k=0∑6​(k100​)(0.08)k(0.92)100−k=0.3032​
